results.headline: Review: ‘Clown’ — At Least Bozo Never Ate the Kids
results.summary_short: This horror film, directed by Jon Watts, finds a man putting on a costume — yes, with a red nose — and becoming a possessed killer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Clown

results.headline: Review: ‘Tickled’ Is Fun and Giggles Until It Isn’t Anymore
results.summary_short: Two filmmakers had barely begun their reporting for this documentary when threats from the private world of tickling began.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tickled

results.display_title: Department Q: a Conspiracy of Faith
results.headline: Review: ‘A Conspiracy of Faith’ Tracks a Message Written in Blood
results.summary_short: This thriller is by far the darkest of the Department Q stories. For this pitch-black film trilogy, that’s saying something.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Department Q: a Conspiracy of Faith

results.display_title: My Love, Don’t Cross That River
results.headline: Review: A Couple’s Adoration After 76 Years of Marriage in ‘My Love, Don’t Cross That River’
results.summary_short: A film that captures the extraordinary love and profound bond of a couple living in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Love, Don’t Cross That River

results.headline: Review: In ‘Parched,’ Women in an Indian Village Chafe Against Oppression
results.summary_short: Despite the appalling events it depicts, Leena Yadav’s film has such affection for its female characters that it often achieves a buoyant tone.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Parched

results.headline: Review: In ‘Seoul Searching,’ Teenagers Explore Their Korean Roots to an ’80s Soundtrack
results.summary_short: Set in 1986, the film introduces globally scattered youngsters to their heritage in a plot that both critiques and embraces stereotypes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seoul Searching

results.display_title: Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story
results.headline: Review: ‘Bang Gang,’ Seaside Orgies to a Soundtrack of Yawns
results.summary_short: This film about middle-class teenagers having group sex during a long hot summer in Biarritz, France, is remarkable for its shrugging attitude.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story

results.headline: Review: ‘Cosmos’ Is a Madcap Plunge Into Retro Avant-Gardism
results.summary_short: The Polish director Andrzej Zulawski’s final film is a witty and energetic — if somewhat labored — mélange of styles and ideas in a cosmopolitan mode.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cosmos

results.display_title: Raiders: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made
results.headline: Review: In ‘Raiders!,’ Two Boys’ First, Great Movie Crush
results.summary_short: In 1982, two Mississippi boys set out to create a shot-by-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s “Raiders of the Lost Ark.” This is their story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Raiders: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made

results.headline: Review: In ‘Argentina,’ a Call to Save Traditions
results.summary_short: Carlos Saura’s film captures a wide array of artists as they perform the folk music and dances of Argentina.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Argentina

results.headline: Review: In ‘Central Intelligence,’ a Weaponized Kevin Hart
results.summary_short: This espionage comedy, which also stars Dwayne Johnson, accomplishes its mission of being aggressively juvenile.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Central Intelligence

results.display_title: Department Q: The Keeper of Lost Causes
results.headline: Review: ‘The Keeper of Lost Causes,’ Pitch-Black Nordic Noir
results.summary_short: Detective Carl Morck has one mood, and boy, it’s bad. The film, based on a novel by Jussi Adler-Olsen, is part of “The Department Q Trilogy.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Department Q: The Keeper of Lost Causes

results.headline: Review: ‘Land and Shade,’ Set Among Colombia’s Sugar Farmers
results.summary_short: A Colombian farmer returns home after years away to be with his ill son in this film, which won best first feature at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Land and Shade

results.display_title: 2016 Sundance Film Festival Short Film Tour
results.headline: Review: Sundance Film Festival Short Films, a Group of Hits and Misses
results.summary_short: A touring program from this year’s lineup, including “The Procedure,” “Bacon & God’s Wrath,” “Justice” and more, is opening at the IFC Center.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Finding Dory,’ a Forgetful Fish and a Warm Celebration of Differences
results.summary_short: The friendly blue fish with short-term memory problems goes looking for her family and takes a star turn in this sequel to “Finding Nemo.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Dory

results.headline: Review: ‘Call Her Applebroog,’ Beth B’s Portrait of a Still-Vital Artist
results.summary_short: Beth B, Ida Applebroog’s daughter, takes an intimate look at the artist’s drawings, paintings and emphatic engagement with others.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Call Her Applebroog

results.headline: Review: In ‘Len and Company,’ a Prickly Pop Producer Finds His Solitude Interrupted
results.summary_short: Rhys Ifans stars as a disaffected former rock star who retreats to the countryside after a meltdown, only to host some surprise guests with concerns of their own.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Len and Company

results.headline: Review: In ‘King Jack,’ a 15-Year-Old Trapped in a Cycle of Bullying
results.summary_short: Felix Johnson’s coming-of-age story portrays a teenage boy in a small town in which a bully exercises his capacity for cruelty.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King Jack

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Conjuring 2,’ Ghostly Violence Has a British Accent
results.summary_short: James Wan’s sequel to his horror hit concerns a London poltergeist in 1977. Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson return as paranormal investigators.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Conjuring 2

results.headline: Review: Brian De Palma Says He Is Hitchcock’s True Heir
results.summary_short: In the documentary “De Palma,” Mr. De Palma explores his muse, and the juxtaposition of images from both of their works goes beyond glib shorthand.
